title: She designs homes for Rich Listers – but won't say who
text:
This is not a one-size-fits-all operation: “A lot of our clients know each other, so it’s important we don’t double-up on anything,” Bragg says. “Everything is made specifically for that client. That’s why they come to me. That’s what makes it high end. And that’s what I enjoy most, coming up with something individual every time.” Such bespoke service comes at a price, though Bragg won’t be drawn into divulging rates.

It’s a far cry from her childhood, spent on a mountain in Scone, NSW. “Life wasn’t about pretty things. And we didn’t come off the mountain very often,” she says. Bragg had no interest in art at school, but she remembers an unusual response to colour. “My dad used to buy big sheets of stamps, and I’d look at the spots down the side, which I think were the colour codes, though I didn’t understand it at the time. Those spots! Still if I see them, something physical happens to me.”

Her mother gave Bragg and her two brothers a garden bed to do what they liked with, and that bloomed into an interest in floristry. She signed up for an evening class, and to pay for the flowers, took a job at Laura Ashley. “Gradually, the flowers morphed into interiors.” From there she became an assistant at Colefax & Fowler, the renowned English decorators who specialise in fabric and wallpaper. “I was useless,” she says, with a grimace. “No, really, I was. My boss, a wonderful woman called Martine Burns, used to re-type my letters when I’d gone home. But she must have seen something. It became almost an apprenticeship.”

Gretel Packer (seen here at a 2015 fundraiser) was a school friend of Bragg's, and together they launched an interior business in 1989. AAP

At lunchtime, she’d meet up with her school friend Gretel Packer (“Her mum and my dad are cousins”) and chat about the fun they’d have working together. Both were keen on design, and Packer was blessed with a head for numbers, so they made it happen, launching an interior design business in 1989.

“I don’t think I’d be so brave now, but I was a baby,” says Bragg, who was 21 at the time. “I didn’t think I had anything to lose.”

With no further ado, the cogs of pre-internet social networking clicked into gear. “It was the eastern suburbs of Sydney and we were very lucky that people talked about us socially. That was definitely an advantage to begin with, but that will only get you so far. After that, you have to produce the goods.”

After the thrill of their first commission – a worker’s cottage in Woollahra – she remembers periods when they “had to work very hard to keep it going, to get the next job”. They ran the business for almost five years, before Packer temporarily relocated to the UK. “She’s still my dear friend, and she’s also a very wise counsel for me. If there are big decisions to make, I quite often call her.”

These days, Bragg owns the business outright, and loves the freedom that brings. It meant she could scale things back when she moved to Melbourne and had children (three boys, now 14, 13 and 12). “Then we cranked it back up when my youngest turned five. That flexibility has been incredibly special. And I love the fact my kids are used to a working mother.”

Advertisement

She’s proud to have brought this pragmatic approach to work-life balance into her studio, where she employs 10 people – all women, but that wasn’t a conscious decision (71.2 per cent of interior designers in Australia are female).

“There’s no drama when someone needs to go to the dentist, or stay home with poorly children. Kids come in after school and do their homework while their mums work. You can have a career, you can have a life, and you can be a nice person. It’s a really warm, welcoming work environment. It takes immense effort, and it creates an immense loyalty. It’s one of my greatest successes of the past 30 years.”

I like layers. I like fabric. I like comfort. And we have a lot of clients who want comfort too. — Adelaide Bragg

Bragg’s decorating style has remained true to itself over the years. If a prospective client wants something that’s not the right fit for her company – “say, an ultra-modern house” – she’ll refer them to former team members who’ve moved on to start their own businesses.

So what does she think of the current trend for minimalism – polished concrete, industrial fittings, frill-free furnishings? “I admire it – some of it’s extraordinary – but it’s not me,” she says. “I can’t live in it, and I can’t decorate that way because that’s not who I am. I like layers. I like fabric. I like comfort. And we have a lot of clients who want comfort too. It’s that classic, timeless look that we do. We don’t do trends, or themes. It’s a home, not a stage set.”

She’s well aware of the civilised world’s fascination with home makeover shows, and is horrified by the concept of the big reveal. “No, no, no,” she shudders. “You don’t want clients getting a surprise. We want the absolute opposite. Too much money is changing hands to risk giving them something they’re not expecting. That’s why the paperwork side of our business takes up 70 per cent of the team’s time. Our quoting is very detailed, right down to what piping is on a cushion, so the client knows exactly what to expect.”

Ah, yes – that clientele. How do they find the whole experience? Anthony Baillieu hired Bragg to work on his Yarram Park property near the Grampians not long ago. Before engaging her services, he’d seen her work in the homes of friends – no, he won’t say who – and that was key. “We’ve known Adelaide and her family for a long time, which can be a good thing and a bad thing,” he points out. “My rationale is that if you’re going to use a friend, make sure you know a lot about them professionally. If it ends in a bad way, it’s easy to lose an interior decorator, but you don’t want to get rid of a friend at the same time.”

If my brother was using Adelaide, she would not tell me about it. She does not discuss anything with anyone. — Anthony Ballieu

What stood out was her collaborative way of working. “A lot of designers are ‘my way or the highway’,” says Baillieu. “Adelaide certainly doesn’t go in there and take over. She gets to know the client, understands what they want, then quietly puts her ideas in front of them.”

Advertisement

Meanwhile, he concurs that our attempts to break her confidentiality are futile. “If my brother was using Adelaide Bragg, she would not tell me about it,” he laughs. “She does not discuss anything with anyone.”

So, what’s next? After decorating everything from secret government properties to house boats, is she feeling the urge to hang up her swatches? Not remotely. “The best thing I did is turn 50. It’s a wonderful stage of life. I was young for so long in the industry, and now I’m not. And what’s great is that it’s a business that enables people to become older.” (The average age of interior designers in Australia is 39.5.)

Recently, she branched out with a side business, Bragg & Co, to produce the type of homewares that are difficult to source for clients. It’s a diversification she works on with her “extraordinary” husband, Tim, who runs a retirement village in regional Victoria. “He’s very flexible with that, so he can be hands-on with the children,” she says. “He also takes an interest in my business. Bragg & Co is something we find really fun to do together.”

As for our insatiable urge to stickybeak inside beautiful homes? That’s just a part of modern life that keeps Bragg on her toes.

“These days the world is very educated on my industry. It’s so visual, which makes it perfect for Instagram,” she says. “So for us, it’s even more important to produce something that is really special. It’s for you. Your neighbour doesn’t have it. Your friend doesn’t have it.

“That’s what we do. And I love it.”

description: For 30 years, Melbourne-based interior designer Adelaide Bragg has been styling and decorating the homes of Australia’s most influential power players.
